questions.question: An airplane is flying at altitude 200 m and at a constant velocity to the East. Which of the following is true? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Since the altitude (height = 200 m) is constant, gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) is constant. Since velocity is constant, kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²) is also constant.

questions.question: A child on a swing is at the highest point of their motion. At this instant:
options: Kinetic energy is maximum, potential energy is minimum
Kinetic energy is zero, potential energy is maximum
Kinetic energy is maximum, potential energy is maximum
Kinetic energy is zero, potential energy is zero
questions.explanation: At the highest point of a swing, the child momentarily stops (velocity = 0), so kinetic energy is zero. Since height is maximum at this point, gravitational potential energy is maximum.

questions.question: A rock is dropped from a cliff. As it falls (ignoring air resistance):
options: Its potential energy increases and kinetic energy decreases
Its potential energy decreases and kinetic energy increases
Both potential and kinetic energy increase
Both potential and kinetic energy decrease
questions.explanation: As the rock falls, its height decreases, so gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) decreases. By conservation of mechanical energy (no air resistance), this lost PE is converted into kinetic energy, so KE increases.

questions.question: A car accelerates from rest to 60 km/h on a level road. During this acceleration:
options: Kinetic energy increases, potential energy is constant
Kinetic energy is constant, potential energy increases
Both kinetic and potential energy increase
Both kinetic and potential energy are constant
questions.explanation: On a level road, height doesn't change, so gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) remains constant. As the car's speed increases from 0 to 60 km/h, its kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²) increases.

questions.question: A book is lifted from the floor to a shelf. During the lifting:
options: Work is done on the book, increasing its potential energy
No work is done because the book ends at rest
Work is done on the book, decreasing its potential energy
The book does work on the person lifting it
questions.explanation: The person applies an upward force on the book through a displacement (upward). Since force and displacement are in the same direction, positive work is done on the book. This work increases the book's gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh increases as height increases).

questions.question: A pendulum swings from its highest point to its lowest point. During this motion:
options: Both PE and KE remain constant
questions.explanation: As the pendulum descends from highest to lowest point, its height decreases, so PE decreases. By conservation of mechanical energy (assuming no friction), this lost PE is converted into KE, so the pendulum speeds up.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward. Halfway to its maximum height:
questions.explanation: At the launch point, all energy is KE. At maximum height, all energy is PE. Halfway up in terms of height, the ball still has more than half its original KE (since KE decreases non-linearly with height due to v²), so KE > PE at the halfway height point.

questions.question: A satellite orbits Earth in an elliptical orbit. At its closest approach (perigee):
options: KE is minimum, PE is maximum
KE is maximum, PE is minimum
Both KE and PE are maximum
Both KE and PE are minimum
questions.explanation: At perigee (closest to Earth), the satellite is at its lowest height, so gravitational PE is minimum. By conservation of mechanical energy, KE must be maximum at this point to maintain constant total energy.

questions.question: A spring is compressed and held at rest. The compressed spring has:
questions.explanation: When held at rest after compression, the spring has zero kinetic energy (not moving). The compressed spring stores energy as elastic potential energy (PE_elastic = ½kx²), which is maximum when compressed or stretched maximally.

questions.question: A bicyclist coasts down a hill without pedaling. Ignoring friction:
questions.explanation: As the bicyclist descends the hill, height decreases, so gravitational PE decreases. This lost PE is converted to KE (assuming no friction), so speed and KE increase.

questions.question: A roller coaster car is at the bottom of a dip moving very fast. At this point:
options: KE is maximum, PE is minimum
KE is minimum, PE is maximum
KE is maximum, PE is maximum
KE is minimum, PE is minimum
questions.explanation: At the bottom of a dip, height is minimum, so gravitational PE is minimum. By energy conservation, KE must be maximum at this lowest point (all the PE from higher points has been converted to KE).

questions.question: An object is thrown upward at an angle. At the highest point of its trajectory:
options: Vertical velocity is zero, horizontal velocity is not zero
questions.explanation: At the highest point, the vertical component of velocity is zero, but the horizontal component (if any) remains constant (ignoring air resistance). Therefore KE is not zero (unless thrown straight up). PE is maximum at the highest point. Total mechanical energy is constant and positive.

questions.question: A car drives up a hill at constant speed. During the ascent:
questions.explanation: Constant speed means KE (½mv²) is constant. As the car gains height, gravitational PE (mgh) increases. The engine does work to increase PE while maintaining constant KE (overcoming gravity and friction).

questions.question: A diver jumps off a diving board. Between leaving the board and hitting the water:
options: Total mechanical energy first increases then decreases
questions.explanation: Ignoring air resistance, the diver's total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant throughout the fall due to conservation of mechanical energy (only conservative force—gravity—is doing work).

questions.question: A box slides to a stop on a rough horizontal floor. During the sliding:
options: KE is converted to thermal energy
questions.explanation: Friction does negative work, converting the box's kinetic energy into thermal energy (heat) and sound. The box's total mechanical energy decreases, but total energy (including thermal) is conserved.

questions.question: A basketball bounces on the floor. After several bounces, it comes to rest. This shows that:
options: Total energy is conserved but mechanical energy is not
Potential energy is always greater than kinetic energy
Kinetic energy increases with each bounce
questions.explanation: With each bounce, some mechanical energy (KE + PE) is converted to thermal energy and sound due to air resistance and deformation of the ball. Total energy (including thermal/sound) is conserved, but mechanical energy decreases until the ball stops.

questions.question: A wind turbine converts ________ energy into electrical energy.
questions.explanation: Wind turbines convert the kinetic energy of moving air (wind) into electrical energy through rotation of blades connected to a generator.

questions.question: A hydroelectric dam generates electricity by converting:
questions.explanation: Water stored at height behind a dam has gravitational potential energy. As it falls through turbines, this PE is converted to kinetic energy of moving water, which then rotates turbines to generate electricity.

scoreMessages.50: You're getting there! Focus on the formulas KE = ½mv² and PE = mgh, and practice identifying energy transformations.
